messages.message: @Serenamy understanding was that the performance issues we observed with editing  custom functions came from us saving on every keystroke. We’ve never shown `(outdated)` next to the validation result and I’d want to understand why we can show `(outdated)` for fields w/ a custom function in the result table but not validation rules — or does that limitation exist for both?

the limitation exists for both—we can show outdated next to the validation result, and we'd have the same problem of updating every keystroke.

i think there _is_ a way to get that `outdated` immediately after typing while maintaining performance, probably with useDeferredValue (https://react.dev/reference/react/useDeferredValue) or something. there might be an even simpler way, the key idea just being that we only need to update it on first keystroke and on blur. the solution we have now is simplest, but if the behavior isn't wanted, it shouldn't be too hard to change i think?

> the limitation exists for both—we can show outdated next to the validation result, and we’d have the same problem of updating every keystroke.
yes thanks for clarifying, this is what i meant

> i think there _is_ a way to get that `outdated` immediately after typing while maintaining performance
agreed, and i think we all agree the ideal UX is to see “outdated” as soon as the code is changed

let’s go back to the drawing board for the implementation of this

if we update the frontend state such that we show “outdated” immediately after typing, then we will no longer need to run the code whenever the user clicks outside of the code editor
